value: <l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">14</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">distinct from the 
            <choice>
              <sic>mistrel</sic>
              <corr>minstrel</corr>
            </choice>, whose words are printed.</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">For when familiar 
            <choice>
              <sic>lettres</sic>
              <corr>letters</corr>
            </choice> are written in Biblical prose</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">there must be a barrier between what is sayable and what</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">unsayable. There is a limit to what can be put</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">into words. He cannot talk; he cannot sing. <add hand="ms">[illeg.]</add> At the beginning</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">of the sixteenth 
            <choice>
              <sic>cnstury</sic>
              <corr>century</corr>
            </choice> he exists; the printing press has</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">given him a name; but he is still unspecialised.</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">The man <add hand="ms" place="above">[with?]</add> who stands outside desiring by some impulse to 
            <choice>
              <sic>obsev</sic>
              <corr>observe</corr>
            </choice></l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">, to state, rather than to take part, is not yet wholly</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">writer, wholly musician or 
            <choice>
              <sic>whllly</sic>
              <corr>wholly</corr>
            </choice> painter. It seems possible</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">that the great English art 
            <choice>
              <sic>ma</sic>
              <corr>may</corr>
            </choice> not be the art of words.</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">He still has the exact 
            <choice>
              <sic>observan</sic>
              <corr>observant</corr>
            </choice> eye <add hand="ms" place="above">that sees exactly </add>; his ear is stimulated</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">by the sound of words spoken aloud. His words must have body</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">and 
            <choice>
              <sic>substnace</sic>
              <corr>substance</corr>
            </choice>, <add hand="ms" place="inline">H</add>e must make them <add hand="ms" place="above">words</add> 
            <choice>
              <sic>sornous</sic>
              <corr>sonorous</corr>
            </choice>, since they are to</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">be read out aloud. <quote source="#" rend="inline">I spent most of my time"</quote> wrote Lady</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><rs type="person" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#psn-aclif" key="Clifford, Ann">Ann Clifford</rs> <quote source="#" rend="inline">"in 
            <choice>
              <sic>playin</sic>
              <corr>playing</corr>
            </choice> at Glecko and hearing <rs type="person" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#psn-mnev" key="Neville, Moll">Moll Neville</rs></quote></l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><quote source="#" rend="inline">read the <rs type="literary-work" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#lit-arca" key="Countess of Pembroke's Arcadia"/>....Rivers used to read to me in</quote></l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><quote source="#" rend="inline"><rs type="person" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#psn-mmon" key="Montaigne, Michel de">Montaignes</rs> <rs type="person" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#lit-essa" key="Essais (Michel de Montaigne)">Essays and Moll Neville in the <rs type="../resources/annotations.xml#lit-faer" key="Faerie Queene, The">Faery Queen</rs>."</rs></quote></l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">
            <choice>
              <sic>Futher</sic>
              <corr>Further</corr>
            </choice>, words must <del hand="ms">
              <choice>
                <sic>yeild</sic>
                <corr>yield</corr>
              </choice> themselves</del> <add hand="ms" place="above">move</add> easily to the lilt</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">of the singing voice, to the virginals<add place="inline" hand="ms">,</add> to the lute. The</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">
            <choice>
              <sic>Eoglish</sic>
              <corr>English</corr>
            </choice> were a musical race. <add hand="ms" place="above">For the English were [always?] singing & playing</add> When 
            <choice>
              <sic>Londonwas</sic>
              <corr>London was</corr>
            </choice> burning</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><rs type="person" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#psn-spep" key="Pepys, Samuel">Pepys</rs> noted that <quote source="#" rend="inline">"hardly one lighter or boat in three</quote></l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><quote source="#" rend="inline">that had the goods of a house in it, but there was a pair</quote></l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><quote source="#" rend="inline">of virginals in it."</quote> <del hand="ms">These were</del> the influences that</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">told upon the poet; <add hand="ms" place="above">[illeg.] moved</add> Under neath the words<add hand="ms" place="inline">:</add> the old words</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">the new words <add hand="ms" place="above">the <del>[illeg.]</del></add>, the 
            <choice>
              <sic>Frechand</sic>
              <corr>French and</corr>
            </choice> the Latin moved the music.</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">No grammar bound them tightly to gether. They could be read</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">aloud; danced to and sung to. But they could not follow the</l>

<add xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" place="margin">
            <l>His senses are</l>
            <l>attuned then:</l>
            <l>he sees within</l>
            <l>shadow</l>
          </add>
